cab.content: This document is the property of His Britannic Majesty's Government.SECRET.CP. 2334 73THE CABINET.EGYPTIAN COTTON CONTROL SCHEME. MEMORANDUM BY THE SECRETARY OF STATE FOR WAR. I circulate herewith a memorandum prepared in the War Office with regard tothe proposal contained in Lord Curzon's Memorandum of 1st Decemher (CP. 2221)to allocate one-half of His Majesty's Governments share of the surplus CottonControl funds to the Egyptian Government for the relief of disabled members of theEgyptian Labour Corps and the dependants of those who lost their lives. W. S. C. THE WAE OFFICE, 21st December, 1920. With reference to paragraph 6 of Cabinet Paper 2221, the present scale of compensation for disability or death for members of the Egyptian Labour Corps and their dependants gives gratuities not exceeding one year's pay of the injured (or deceased) man. This scale is similar to that applicable to several enrolled native corps (including the Greek and Malta Labour Corps), and is that which was contracted for on enrolment. There is no obligation on the War Office to increase the awards already made, and the request of Lord Allenby is based on political considerations. The application of the Egyptian Pension Laws as proposed by Lord Allenby would result (according to his estimate) in an immediate charge of about 100,000/. for increased gratuities, and an annual charge of 50,000/. a year. If the total charge for pensions is taken at 10 years' purchase of the annual charge, the total liability involved in the proposal is about 600,000/. ; but the War Office at present has no means of checking Lord Allenby's figures. No case has been made out for adding so considerable a charge to Army Estimates, but if refusal of the proposal is likely to prejudice the Government in settling the allocation of the Surplus Cotton Control Funds, no objection is offered to the suggestion that the Egyptian Government be left to carry out their proposal at the expense of-Egyptian funds, a corresponding allowance being made from the portion of the Surplus Cotton Control Funds retained by His Majesty's Government as their share.(B20/518) 100 12/20 H&S, Ltd. 8819wo
